title: Marvin J. Ashton
text:
Marvin Jeremy Ashton (May 6, 1915 – February 25, 1994) was a <a href="Utah">Utah</a> politician and a member of the <a href="Quorum%20of%20the%20Twelve%20Apostles%20%28LDS%20Church%29">Quorum of the Twelve Apostles</a> of <a href="The%20Church%20of%20Jesus%20Christ%20of%20Latter-day%20Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a> (LDS Church) from 1971 until his death in 1994.
Ashton was born to <a href="Marvin%20O.%20Ashton">Marvin O. Ashton</a> and Rachel Grace Jeremy in <a href="Salt%20Lake%20City">Salt Lake City</a>, <a href="Utah">Utah</a>. His father was a local LDS leader and later became a church <a href="general%20authority">general authority</a>. Ashton worked in the lumber business as a youth. He graduated from the <a href="University%20of%20Utah">University of Utah</a>. He worked as managing director of <a href="Family%20Services">LDS Social Services</a>. Ashton served as a member of the <a href="Utah%20State%20Senate">Utah State Senate</a> from 1957 to 1961 as a <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a>. He was also president of <a href="Deseret%20Book">Deseret Book</a> and involved in other business ventures including a lumber company.
LDS Church service.
Ashton served a <a href="Mormon%20missionary">mission</a> in <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> from 1937 to 1939 during which time he edited the "<a href="Millennial%20Star">Millennial Star</a>". His <a href="mission%20president">mission president</a> was <a href="Hugh%20B.%20Brown">Hugh B. Brown</a>. From 1958 to 1969, Ashton was an assistant to the general superintendent of the church's <a href="Young%20Men%27s%20Mutual%20Improvement%20Association">Young Men's Mutual Improvement Association</a>. He served as an assistant to superintendents <a href="Joseph%20T.%20Bentley">Joseph T. Bentley</a> and <a href="G.%20Carlos%20Smith">G. Carlos Smith</a>.
He was named managing director of the then-newly formed Church Social Services Department in September of 1969. A month later he was named an <a href="Assistant%20to%20the%20Quorum%20of%20the%20Twelve%20Apostles">Assistant to the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles</a>. 
Ashton was ordained an <a href="Apostle%20%28Latter%20Day%20Saints%29">apostle</a> on December 2, 1971, after the death of <a href="Richard%20L.%20Evans">Richard L. Evans</a>. Among his assignments, he was president of the <a href="Polynesian%20Cultural%20Center">Polynesian Cultural Center</a> and a member of the board of trustees of <a href="Brigham%20Young%20University%E2%80%93Hawaii">Brigham Young University–Hawaii</a>.
Ashton died on February 25, 1994, and at the time of his death was serving as chairman of the church's Leadership Training Committee and was also a member of both the Correlation Executive and the General Welfare Services committees. The vacancy created in the Quorum of the Twelve was filled by <a href="Robert%20D.%20Hales">Robert D. Hales</a>.
Personal life.
Ashton married Norma Berntson in the <a href="Salt%20Lake%20Temple">Salt Lake Temple</a> on August 22, 1940, and they were the parents of four children. They won the mixed doubles championship in the all-church tennis tournament in 1954. Ashton was involved with the <a href="Boy%20Scouts%20of%20America">Boy Scouts of America</a> most of his life and earned <a href="Eagle%20Scout%20%28Boy%20Scouts%20of%20America%29">Eagle Scout</a> as an adult in 1963. As an adult he was a recipient of the <a href="Distinguished%20Eagle%20Scout%20Award">Distinguished Eagle Scout Award</a>, the <a href="Silver%20Beaver%20Award">Silver Beaver Award</a>, and the <a href="Silver%20Antelope%20Award">Silver Antelope Award</a>.
